column1: Coalition protects wealthy retirees’ investments under cover of Covid-19 pandemic
column2: The Coalition moved to protect the superannuation of Australia's wealthiest retirees at the same time it was encouraging the nation's poorest to raid their retirement accounts. And they continue to protect the wealthiest even though the Australian share market is back at record highs. Elizabeth Minter reports.

column1: Who to believe on Bondi Cluster: Limousine Man or NSW Government?
column2: Data published, and quickly updated, by the NSW Department of Health reveals there may have been locally acquired cases in NSW on June 13, four days before “Limousine Man” was recorded as being the Bondi Cluster's "Patient Zero". Callum Foote investigates the mess that is Covid data.

column1: Bali is leading the vaccination race, welcoming tourists soon, but not Australians
column2: Bali will soon have vaccinated 80% of its population over 18 years of age. And it may open up to tourism again within a month or two. But Australians need not apply.

column1: Sports rorter Bridget McKenzie back on the front bench courtesy of Barnaby Joyce
column2: Bridget McKenzie was forced to resign in February 2020 after the "sports rorts" affair but, as are the ways of the National Party, misdeeds are quickly forgotten if you back the right leader at the right time. So just like her good buddy, recently resurrected National Party Leader Barnaby Joyce, McKenzie is back on the Coalition government front bench as Minister for Regionalisation, Regional education and Regional Communications.

column1: CitiPower, Powercor: What’s the Scam?
column2: Scammer exposed! A fitting title for the latest financial accounts of billionaire-owned electricity giant Victoria Power Networks, the largest energy operator in Victoria which runs the CitiPower and Powercor networks. But are they getting off with a light sentence from the Tax Office?

column1: Carbon Bomb Beetaloo: world goes net zero, yet Coalition steps on the gas, Labor nods
column2: Tracts the size of Bulgaria open for oil and gas exploration, along with generous government subsidies for foreign oil companies. Just as the world is tackling climate change, Australia is accelerating its fossil fuel production, and in almost every state and territory. Callum Foote investigates the bizarre hand-outs for a foreign hedge fund drilling for gas and the carve up of the NT's Beetaloo Basin.

column1: Federal bushfire recovery funds. What’s the scam?
column2: Scott Morrison's $2 billion bushfire recovery fund is only "notional", the vast majority of money has gone to the Liberal states of NSW and SA, and there's no transparency to the spending, with a key website changed to make it even more difficult to find information.

column1: CSL and contaminated blood scandal: UK accepts ‘moral responsibility’; Australia still silent
column2: The UK Health Secretary has just admitted his government’s "moral responsibility" for the UK's contaminated blood scandal of the 1970s and 1980s yet Australian victims are still without compensation or even an apology.

column1: NSW pokies: What’s the Scam?
column2: NSW has the world’s worst pokies losses per capita at $7 billion per year, equivalent to more than $1,200 for each adult. It's a boon for the state's coffers but the government is proposing reforms to stem the losses, or is it? What's the scam?

column1: Privacy rights jeopardised with Covid apps tracking every move
column2: Law enforcement agencies have a cavalier attitude to the right to privacy and a “whatever it takes” attitude to raiding databases of personal information, writes Greg Barns. Given the treasure trove of information now available from all the Covid tracing apps, strong penalties and laws are needed to ensure evidence obtained from those apps cannot be used in legal proceedings.

column1: Charities sponsoring death
Jobactive fails jobless while privatised job agencies revel in a record pandemic profit boom
column2: Large job agencies who dominate Australia's privatised employment system are enjoying a boom of record profits, and even a takeover spree, while their disillusioned job seekers complain of churning and profiteering. Meanwhile, those in government on both sides of the political aisle are calling for reform. In this special investigation, Stephanie Tran reports on the failure of Jobactive.

column1: Hayne gets last laugh as “Your Future Your Super” laws deliver for small punters over big bank pals
column2: The new "Your Future, Your Super" legislation avoided the most egregious of changes proposed by the LNP Government. YFYS will simplify and streamline the $3 trillion super system, fix "zombie accounts" and spark fund takeovers, writes Harry Chemay. The changes go some way to addressing a key question posed during the Hayne Royal Commission: "what do trustees do in the dark with our super?"

column1: Power to go to war rests with one man – Scott Morrison – is Parliament okay with that?
column2: Australia is a democracy, yet when it comes to the most critical national decision of sending Australian troops into armed conflict overseas, the power rests with one man, the Prime Minister. This is the curtain-raiser for our #warpowers series as reporter Tasha May calls around Australia's parliamentarians and its people.

column1: Vultures’ Reprise: MacBankers bob up in takeover battle for hapless Sydney Airport
column2: Like the muddy hand from the grave, Macquarie is suddenly circling Sydney Airport again. Michael West reports on the ultimate circus of privatisation, where Macquarie pillaged the most prized asset in Australia, the unregulated monopoly which is this country's gateway to the world, and is shaping up to do it again.

column1: Uber: What’s the Scam?
column2: Lockdown is bliss for some. Uber Australia's accounts are out - late - and the multinational which defines people on mopeds as its "partners", not employees, is coining it. What's the scam?

column1: Zali Steggall on war powers reform
Jordon Steele-John on war powers reform
Josh Wilson on war powers reform
Brendan O’Connor on war powers reform
Pauline Hanson on war power reforms
How Exxon made $80 Billion over 8 years and paid $0 in tax
The Business of Covid: Gladys Berejiklian hides “the health advice” as pandemic threatens Sydney
column2: Despite continual claims she acted on health advice, despite continual pleas to the NSW public to follow the health advice, Premier Gladys Berejiklian let slip that advice from business played a part in her handling of the pandemic and the Sydney lockdown. What is the health advice? Callum Foote and Michael West investigate.

column1: NSW got seven times Victoria’s lockdown subsidies: What’s the Scam?
column2: The Federal Government gave NSW Northern Beaches residents seven times the lockdown support that it gave beleaguered Victorians during their extended lockdown last year. What's the scam?

column1: Who’s Gladys taking public health advice from? Medical or Business?
La Fiesta Barilaro: What’s the Scam?
Money for nothing, debts for free: the RBA, the banks and a negative interest rates warning
column2: As NSW plunges back into lockdown, the banks have been warned to prepare for negative interest rates. Meanwhile, the Reserve Bank has quietly conceded the banks have not lent the $188 billion pandemic stimulus, parking it in their $314b war-chest at the central bank earning no interest. Michael West on the looming storm-clouds for the Australian economy.

column1: NSW got four times Victoria’s lockdown subsidies: What’s the Scam?
column2: The Federal Government gave NSW Northern Beaches residents seven times the lockdown support that it gave beleaguered Victorians during their extended lockdown last year. What's the scam?

column1: War with China: zero logic yet the weapons lobby has 42% of Australians believing it
column2: Incredibly, a survey finds 42% of Australians believe China will attack Australia, this despite exports to China surging 36% over in the last six months, and despite there being no logical rationale for war with China, or an attack by China. Marcus Reubenstein analyses the ludicrous position of Australia's China hawks and the mainstream media pushing their agendas.

column1: John Barilaro’s daughter breaches lockdown twice: What’s the scam?
column2: The ACT Police have confirmed that NSW Deputy Premier John Barilaro's daughter entered Canberra on July 12, breaking the public health order for a second time, having travelled from her home in Queanbeyan to Sydney on July 9. John Barilaro has refused to answer questions about the incident.

column1: Ocean Waste: how plastic recyclers downplay their use of new plastics
column2: Beware recycled plastics. They often contain virgin plastics, the very plastics the recyclers say they are fighting. Luke Stacey investigates green vanguard and their recycling claims and finds, while they do good work in raising public awareness, they could certainly be more transparent.

column1: Macquarie is back to feast on Sydney Airport’s brains!
One-sided War Powers!
Foreign multinational Max Solutions the biggest winner in pandemic jobs crisis
column2: A takeovers binge is in swing in the jobless sector as the biggest private provider of employment services, the foreign multinational Max Solutions mops up smaller players and posts strong revenues from government. Stephanie Tran investigates the Jobactive scheme and the failure of privatisation.

column1: War Powers: four perspectives from politicians who have served
column2: Parliament does not need to be consulted before Australian troops are sent to war. What do the politicians who have donned the uniform have to say? Tasha May asks Rex Patrick, Andrew Wilkie, Jim Molan and Bob Katter.

column1: Sky News poisons the well that Gladys drinks from
Toxic Waste Rebranded: Australia bans Third World dumping, leaves giant toxic loophole
column2: "It's our waste, it's our problem", said Scott Morrison as he announced the nation's waste export ban culminating in 2024. Not really. It's a good thing Australia has banned solid waste dumping to the Third World but we have left a gaping, toxic  loophole; burning plastics for energy. Luke Stacey investigates.

column1: Fencegate: All the Council President’s men … lose their ludicrous lawsuit
column2: His crime was apparently harassing the staff at the local council over a fence, and the obnoxious neighbour on the other side of said fence. Bolton, a Sydney lawyer, was threatened with defamation by Inner West Council chief executive, Michael Deegan, whose lawyers demanded money, then ended up in court facing harassment charges.

column1: Census 2021 is almost upon us: What’s the Scam?
column2: Desperate to avoid a repeat of 'Censusfail 2016', the Australian Bureau of Statistics received $38 million from government coffers to ensure the success of 2021. Will it prove to be money well spent?

column1: Sitting Ducks: spread of Carbon Border Tax schemes leaves Australia defenceless on climate
column2: The sudden, global move to tax carbon puts billions of Australian coal and gas exports at risk, indeed this country's largest sources of income. Hard on the heels of the EU's carbon border tax declaration, the US declared a carbon border scheme. Others are poised to follow. Callum Foote and Michael West report on the immense risk to Australia's largest source of income.

column1: Have the Barilaros avoided GST on their luxury estate? What’s the scam?
column2: It appears John Barilaro, and his wife Diane have avoided paying over a hundred thousand dollars in GST from renting out their luxury getaway ‘Dungowan Estate’ despite it potentially qualifying as a commercial residential premises. What's the scam?

column1: Politicians playing dress up, Unreality TV.
Gas Myths: Australians pay 7th highest prices in world despite being biggest gas exporter
column2: Australia is the biggest exporter of gas, bar none, in the world, yet we are paying the seventh-highest prices for gas in the world. Callum Foote reports on the gas cartel and the myth there is a gas “market”.

column1: Where there’s a bill there’s a way: Rex Patrick’s dogged fight against Coalition to repeal billionaires’ loophole
column2: It's been quite the innings for some of Australia's wealthiest billionaires. Certain large proprietary companies owned by the establishment - Secret Rich-Listers as we call them - have been cloaked in darkness by government legislation for more than a quarter of a century. Luke Stacey reports how South Australian Senator Rex Patrick is fighting to buck the trend and demolish Australia's Secret Rich List once and for all.

column1: State of Surveillance: if Pegasus can hack Jeff Bezos’ phone, is there anywhere to hide?
column2: Israeli firm NSO Group has created spyware which can hack a smartphone, beat encryption and access every bit of our data, live-time, just like reading over somebody’s shoulder. Human rights activist and cyber-security expert Manal al Sharif examines the implications. This is the first in Manal al Sharif’s Tech4Evil series which exposes the threat of Big Tech on our minds, our humanity and democracy itself. Exclusive.

column1: The Belle of the Bull
column2: Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/TheWestReport Merch: https://lonelykidsclub.com/new/michael+west Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/michaelwest.journo Insta: https://www.instagram.com/michaelwestjourno/ #FederalICACNow

column1: Google dodges regulation, hits advertisers with “regulatory” charges: What’s the Scam?
column2: Google's parent Alphabet is making record profits, $US18.5b in the last quarter alone, almost 30% of revenue. But it is not enough, Google feels so aggrieved by the mostly non-existing "digital services regulations", it is charging advertisers more; so a 5% surcharge will be added to Google and YouTube advertisers in some countries from 1 October. What's the scam?

column1: Bludging off Australia: IKEA versus Nick Scali. Both flog couches, one is robbing us
column2: IKEA pays no tax in Australia despite surging sales in the pandemic. IKEA versus Nick Scali. Both sell furniture, only one pays tax. Michael West looks at a quintessential case of multinational tax bludging.

column1: NSW Contact Tracing: “gold standard” or just more Covid spin?
column2: As Sydney Covid infections spiral out of control, the efficiency of NSW's lauded "gold standard" contact tracing system has become ever more critical. Cracks are appearing. Luke Stacey reports.

column1: Is the ACCC protecting telco consumers or fattening up NBNCo for sale?
column2: Is the ACCC helping the Government get the best price for the sale of NBNCo? The competition regulators are doing consumers no favours hindering investment in new telco infrastructure. Who is looking after the interests of telco consumers? asks former NBNCo CTO Gary McLaren.

column1: The Blame Game – How Scott Morrison shirks responsibility
column2: RonniSalt thread: https://twitter.com/RonniSalt/status/1419925195595292683 The Juice Media: https://youtu.be/X_0zFEtPbiA Cal’s Story: https://www.michaelwest.com.au/governments-appalling-error-rejects-offer-of-40-million-pfizer-doses-in-july-2020/ Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/TheWestReport Merch: https://lonelykidsclub.com/new/michael+west Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/michaelwest.journo Insta: https://www.instagram.com/michaelwestjourno/ "Blame Canada" – 1999, South Park: Bigger, Longer & Uncut, written by Trey Parker & Marc Shaiman

column1: Going Nuts: Murray Darling’s “unbelievably beautiful story” for investors a nightmare for farmers, environment
column2: Duxton Water executives have been boasting about “beautiful” structural imbalances in Australia’s water market, and potentially dazzling profits from drought. Corporate nut farming is thirsty business and the proliferation of almond farms is poised to whip up prices and crush traditional agriculture in Australia's food bowl, reports Callum Foote.

column1: Aussies top Olympic medals tally: What’s the Scam?
column2: Australia is beating China, Russia, Japan and the US in the Olympic medals tally - despite claims to the contrary. What's the scam? A new independent expert's report reveals the International Olympics Committee has it all wrong.

column1: The Biggest Robber: Crown caught and confessed as cagey Lendlease covers up
column2: Organised crime haven Crown Resorts or corporate welfare champion Lendlease? Who will win? Michael West reports on the new game show, The Biggest Robber.

column1: Parliament’s Department of Cover-Ups faces bullying claims, tangle of lawsuits
column2: The Government department which covered up the security report into the alleged rape of Brittany Higgins is also the department found to have a culture of bullying, and is also the department whose staffer is threatening multiple legal actions against small publishers and other Australians. What is going on at Parliament House? Michael West investigates the Department of Parliamentary Services.

column1: Pfizer: What’s the Scam?
column2: Tax cheat Pfizer had a thoroughly pleasing pandemic year, paying zero tax in Australia last year on a billion dollars in sales. What's the scam?

column1: Jobactive providers mooching off the unemployed and the taxpayer
column2: The Story: https://www.michaelwest.com.au/jobactive-investigation-pandemic-boom-for-privatised-job-agencies-not-great-for-job-seekers/ Foreign multinational Max Solutions the biggest winner in pandemic jobs crisis Pandemic goldmine for private unemployment agencies as Coalition boosts payments Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/TheWestReport Merch: https://lonelykidsclub.com/new/michael+west Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/michaelwest.journo Insta: https://www.instagram.com/michaelwestjourno/

column1: ASIC charging 130% late fees to small business. What’s the scam?
column2: ASIC – the Australian Securities and Investment Commission – manages the register of businesses as part of its remit. If you have a company it will charge you $267* per annum for the privilege. But whatever you do, don’t pay that bill late! Miss the due date by a few months and the late charge […

column1: Energy to Waste: Australia moves on plastics yet falls short in world recycling race
column2: As petrochemical giants plan to double new plastics production and the bulk of Australian plastics are tipped into landfill, not recycled, Luke Stacey checks out how other countries are tackling the plastics crisis versus the Coalition Government's 2025 National Packaging Targets and waste export bans.

column1: My feelings are hurt, GIVE ME YOUR HOUSE!

column1: Recycling plastic means you can burn it yeah?
column2: Luke’s Stories: PET Project: petrochemical giants exploit recycling to ramp up plastics production Ocean Waste: how plastic recyclers downplay their use of new plastics Toxic Waste Rebranded: Australia bans Third World dumping, leaves giant toxic loophole Energy to Waste: Australia moves on plastics yet falls short in world recycling race Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/TheWestReport Merch: https://lonelykidsclub.com/new/michael+west Facebook: […]

column1: Melissa Price on war powers reform
Pauline Hanson Buckles: billionaires beat Parliament again
column2: It has been 26 years, 26 years of the wealthiest Australians, the billionaires, subverting Australia’s Parliament, their lobbyists calling MPs and their staffers, and donating to the major parties to help keep their loophole intact. Luke Stacey and Michael West report.

column1: Adam Bandt on war powers reform
column2: Adam Bandt wants reform. Leader of the Australian Greens, Adam Bandt, moved a bill in February this year in the...

column1: Kevin Andrews on war powers reform
column2: When asked if he believed Parliament should be consulted before Australian troops are sent into armed conflict abroad, Federal Liberal...

column1: Survival of the Witless: how a government so corrupt and incompetent clings to power
column2: Barnaby maggoted in Parliament, billionaires schmoozed, JobKeeper for Royal Sydney Golf Club. Unprecedented rorting of public money, abject failure on the Covid vaccinations and climate change. Michael West investigates how a government so corrupt and so incompetent manages to survive.

column1: Third, Oh Really? ABC News swallows Coalition data spin
column2: ABC News is showing its extensive audience that growth in gross domestic product (GDP) ranks third in the world - 23rd is closer to the mark
